newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Writedown trims NZ govt surplus by NZ$126 mln.
newsitem.headline: Writedown trims NZ govt surplus by NZ$126 mln.

text.p: A writedown in the value of the government's investment in Forestry Corporation of New Zealand will trim NZ$126 million from the government operating surplus for the 1995/96 year.

Finance Minister Bill Birch said on Thursday the revision of the book value of Forestry Corp from $1.724 billion to $1.598 billion on June 30 was revealed on Tuesday when the government announced the sale to a Fletcher Challenge-led consortium, but it had not been picked up by the media.
The government netted $1.6 billion from the sale.

In an August 16 speech to a business forum in Auckland, Birch said the operating surplus would be slightly below forecast figures due to a $328 million court settlement against the Crown over the sale of New Zealand Steel to collapsed investment company Equiticorp in 1987, and "significant downward adjustments in the valuation of some assets".
As a matter of policy the Treasury does not include fluctuations in the value of the Crown's forestry holdings among risk factors in its forecasts.
On Budget night last May the government was forecasting an operating surplus of $3.9 billion for the June 1995/96 year.
The government's final accounts for the 1995/96 year will be released on September 12. -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
